title: Direct Visualization of Metal Sintering and Powder Bed Fusion of 316 Stainless Steel Powders via In Situ Scanning Electron Microscopy
content: Additive manufacturing (3D printing) technology has fundamentally altered the landscape of manufacturing, introducing the capability to produce intricate shapes and architectures previously deemed unachievable or overly complex for conventional machining or casting processes. One of the most prominent methods in this field is known as Laser Powder Bed Fusion (LPBF). This technique leverages the power of a focused, high-energy laser beam to selectively melt and bond powder particles together, layer-by-layer, to construct objects in a three-dimensional form. The printing process utilizes a reservoir filled with powder material, encompassing a wide range of meltable substances including various metals [1] and different types of polymers [2]. A thin layer of powder is spread from the reservoir onto the print area and selectively melted following computer-aided design (CAD); this process is repeated layer by layer to manufacture the desired object and a 50 Î¼m feature resolution has been previously shown [3].
